definition: **noun / hi-fi deck type.** A **turntable that automatically lifts and returns the tonearm at the end of the record** but requires manual cueing at the start. The mechanism uses a trigger arm or sensor positioned near the lead-out groove that activates when the stylus reaches the record's end, engaging a motor-driven mechanism to lift the tonearm and return it to its rest position. Most models also shut off the platter motor automatically. Introduced in the 1960s alongside fully-automatic designs, semi-automatic turntables became the preferred format for serious listeners who wanted manual cueing control for precise placement but appreciated automated protection against stylus wear and groove damage from run-out loops. Classic examples include the Technics SL-23, Dual CS-505, and Pioneer PL-570, which dominated the mid-fi market through the 1970s and 1980s. The format represents a practical compromise between the hands-on engagement of manual decks and the convenience of fully-automatic changers, though audiophiles sometimes argue the lift mechanism adds complexity that can affect sound quality. Semi-automatic tables experienced renewed interest in the vinyl revival era, with modern reinterpretations like the Audio-Technica AT-LP5x offering the feature to newcomers concerned about record preservation.
etymology: Coined in the 1960s hi-fi industry to distinguish turntables with partial automation from fully-automatic changers and manual-only decks, combining the Latin prefix 'semi-' (half) with 'automatic' from Greek 'automatos' (self-acting).
